title: USS Oahu (ARG-5)
text:
USS "Oahu" (ARG-5) was a <a href="USS%20Luzon%20%28ARG-2%29">"Luzon"-class</a> <a href="internal%20combustion%20engine">internal combustion engine</a> <a href="repair%20ship">repair ship</a> that saw service in the <a href="United%20States%20Navy">United States Navy</a> during <a href="World%20War%20II">World War II</a>. Named for the <a href="Oahu">Island of Oahu</a>, third largest island in the <a href="Hawaiian%20chain">Hawaiian chain</a>, it was the second US Naval vessel to bear the name.
Construction.
"Oahu" was <a href="Keel%20laying">laid down</a> 14 August 1943, as the <a href="liberty%20ship">liberty ship</a> SS "Caleb C. Wheeler", under a <a href="Maritime%20Commission">Maritime Commission</a> (MARCOM) contract, MCE hull 1782, by the <a href="Bethlehem-Fairfield%20Shipyard">Bethlehem-Fairfield Shipyard</a>, Inc., in <a href="Baltimore">Baltimore</a>, Maryland; launched 9 September 1943; sponsored by Mrs. O. F. Hurt; acquired by the Navy from MARCOM 15 September 1943; converted by the <a href="Maryland%20Drydock%20Company">Maryland Drydock Company</a>, <a href="Baltimore">Baltimore</a>, Maryland; and <a href="Ship%20commissioning">commissioned</a> 4 April 1944, <a href="Commander%20%28United%20States%29">Commander</a> Clyde Lovelace in command.
Service history.
Following a <a href="Chesapeake%20Bay">Chesapeake Bay</a> <a href="shakedown%20cruise">shakedown</a>, the repair ship "Oahu" departed <a href="Hampton%20Roads%2C%20Virginia">Hampton Roads, Virginia</a>, 16 May 1944, steaming south and then west. Transiting the <a href="Panama%20Canal">Panama Canal</a>, she headed out into the <a href="Pacific%20Ocean">Pacific</a>. On 8 July, she arrived at <a href="Eniwetok">Eniwetok</a> and on 11 July, began repairing the damaged vessels of the <a href="United%20States%20Pacific%20Fleet">Pacific Fleet</a>. 
"Oahu" remained based at Eniwetok for the greater part of the next eight months. There she kept Allied vessels, naval and merchant, in trim and prepared them for the <a href="Philippine%20Islands">Philippine</a> and <a href="Iwo%20Jima">Iwo Jima</a> operations. Moving forward to <a href="Ulithi">Ulithi</a> at the end of February 1945, she serviced the ships gathering for the invasion of <a href="Okinawa">Okinawa</a> during March and then returned to the <a href="Marshall%20Islands">Marshalls</a>. "Oahu" continued her work at Eniwetok until 6 December, when she got underway for the <a href="United%20States">United States</a>.
Decommissioning and post-war.
Arriving at <a href="San%20Pedro%2C%20California">San Pedro, California</a>, 25 December, "Oahu", having repaired over two thousand ships during the war, was ordered to <a href="San%20Diego%2C%20California">San Diego, California</a>, to complete repair and pre-inactivation work on vessels going into mothballs.
On 22 November she herself was ordered inactivated, and decommissioned in January 1947. She was berthed at San Diego as a unit of the <a href="Pacific%20Reserve%20Fleet">Pacific Reserve Fleet</a> until transferred 13 March 1962, and laid up at <a href="Suisun%20Bay">Suisun Bay</a>. On 1 July 1963, she was permanently transferred to the <a href="Maritime%20Administration">Maritime Administration</a> (MARAD). She remained there as a unit of the <a href="National%20Defense%20Reserve%20Fleet">National Defense Reserve Fleet</a> until being sold to <a href="General%20Metals%20of%20Tacoma%2C%20Inc.">General Metals of Tacoma, Inc.</a>, on 27 March 1978. She was withdrawn 7 June 1978, for scrapping.
Awards.
"Oahu" received one <a href="battle%20star">battle star</a> for <a href="World%20War%20II">World War II</a> service.
